justification: The article states that in a typical cognitive control experiment (e.g., a Stroop ... task) participants must engage control processes to override automatic responses.
Cognitive control experiments are exemplified by "a Stroop, Eriksen flanker, or Simon task," indicating the flanker task is used to index control processes.
The review lists the Simon task alongside Stroop and flanker as standard paradigms where recruiting control is necessary, showing it serves as a control measure.
It describes a typical decision-making experiment as "a choice between two gambles," where participants weigh costs and benefits, illustrating this task operationalizes value-based decisions.
The same sentence lists choosing between "food items" as an example of decision-making experiments that assess how people compute option values.
